Dean was a high school dropout who appeared to be an alcoholic who smoked a lot.I watched part of the special features to see if I could find out why the story was so well acted, but still fell short of a five star rating for me. The director (who also wrote much of the story), Derek Cianfrance, explained that he had always tried to understand the dissolution of his own parents' marriage and wanted to explore the end of a relationship in film. He, Ryan Gosling, and Michelle Williams, had worked on the concept for years before filming began. Ryan and Michelle were also executive producers. I think that when many relationships end, those involved and those who witness the end of the relationship may not fully understand why it ended. In that sense, the movie conveyed that sense of bewilderment extremely well.My recommendation is to rent or borrow it before buying it. It was definitely good enough for me to keep thinking of it long after watching it and I will no doubt view it again. If it appeals to you, it will rate 4 or 5 stars. reviewText: There are moments in `Blue Valentine' that feel so raw and so affecting that you can't help but feel uncomfortable while watching it.  I remember sitting there in the theater and actually getting the urge to leave because I felt like I was intruding on an intimate conversation; one that was laced with aggression.While `Blue Valentine' is undoubtedly depressing and uncomfortable, it culminates into one of the most passionate and ultimately `special' films I've seen in a long time.It's brutally honest, and I respect it immensely for that.Yes, there are no happy endings in `Blue Valentine', which is only one aspect that sticks out so strongly.  Following a young couple, Dean and Cindy, the film focuses on two moments in their relationship; the beginning and the end.  Splicing together fragments of their time together, the film brilliantly contrasts their happy moments with their unhappy ones.  We see them bitterly argue in the car and then watch them flirt bashfully and hesitantly on a train.  We watch them resist each other sexually and then watch them completely give in to each other's advances.  The way that the film is constructed is flawless, layering each emotion with such care and precision.The truth of the matter is that relationships are not perfect.  Love is not infallible.  Life is not gracious and so hard times can fracture even the purest of loves.  What Dean and Cindy had was not special, it was authentic.  It was natural.  It represents what we all could have right now.  Life plays dirty little tricks on us and causes us to fray at the edges, and that's exactly what happened to Dean and Cindy.But like Dean frantically pleads; you promised `for better or for worse'; right?`Blue Valentine' is technically flawless.  The script is sharp and beautifully fleshed out, even in the moments that are not explained.  While we do not see the entire relationship, we see enough `between the lines' to begin to fill in the blanks.  The film is breathlessly edited (those moments just linger) and the cinematography is fantastic (so claustrophobic, so poignant).  But this film is all about those two lead performances.  Both Michelle Williams and Ryan Gosling are BEYOND reproach here.  They emote so much, and they each have to tackle two sides of love (that whole `better' and `worse' thing) and they do it effortlessly.  The way that they can dote on one another and then practically seethe at the mouth is astonishing to watch.I would not be surprised if they remain my favorite performances of this next decade.So, while `Blue Valentine' may be hard to watch, it is a very poignant and universally important film.  It doesn't skirt around the obvious but gives us an inside look at the cracks within the marital bond.  Anyone who's been married (or who still is married) will identify with some of the feelings (or maybe even all of them) floating around the screen.  Marriage is not easy, and people are not easy, and films like `Blue Valentine' help us to see that we are not alone.

reviewText: Some viewers are having a hard time with this film and it is actually understood.  For decades Hollywood has been dishing out the fairy tale love story film with the happily ever after ending or the chick flick films perfect for date night.  These are great for escape or date nights but in no way based on reality.  But film is an art form meant to educate the audience and show them realities and subjects they may not want to see but need to.  For some this film will be too depressing and too dreary.  But this is the first film in decades to so fully and realistically immerse itself into the showing of a relationship that half of this country could be going through.  We have Cindy and Dean who are married with a daughter Frankie.  From the beginning of the film who know all is not well.  There is constant tension between the couple, fights are picked, nasty things are said.  There is passion still so strong but now it comes out as true distaste.  This is our couple years after they met, fell in love and got married.  The story is shown with the problems of present day and flashbacks to the period when they met and fell in love.There is no magic dust to spread over this couple to make all well.  Even when they met all was not perfect.  Cindy came from a verbally abusive household and was pregnant by her current boyfriend when she meets Dean, a high school drop-out working for a moving company.  Dean pursued Cindy and it takes a while to work his way into her good graces.  The story of their growing love is very believable, sometimes sweet but always has its own problems.  In the wrong hands this film could have been a disaster but with writer/director Derek Cianfrance and more secifically the outstanding, superb performances of Michelle Williams and Ryan Gosling this film becomes a masterpiece.  Ms. Williams and Mr. Gosling inhabit these characters so fully the feel at times is like a documentary rather than a movie.  This is far beyond great acting.  Their immersion into these characters puts on the screen emotions so raw, honest and true that the audience often feels like the are spying on a real couple.  There is much ad lib here and the couple lived together for a lengthy time to truly feel like a couple.  These performances show the actors at perhaps the highlight and pinnacle of both their already impeccably impressive careers.In the story the couple decides to spend a night together at a hotel to try and rekindle some spark.  The story is simple and told moreso through the emotions and lives they lead.  There is explicit sex here that plays a major part in the story.  It's not always pretty and truly shows how sometimes sex and affection becomes just routine and mechanical, truly unemotional.  Love means different things to Dean and Cindy and when the film ends there is no true resolution to their relationship.  The viewer will be truly emotionally drained and rather stunned.  But in the hands of Cianfrance the viewer is guided and handled carefully with the fine line never being crossed.  And the lasting impression this film will leave is true respect and admiration for the mutually superb, intense, realistic and ground breaking acting of Michelle Williams and Ryan Gosling.  It is also sad for the viewer to have to acknowledge that there are couples all over the country leading just this sort of life.  Their story deserves to be told just as much as the Hollywood fairy tale.  Be prepared before viewing this film and you will be shown what a film in the correct hands can truly deliver.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: WARNING - SPOILER ALERT!!It's so rare to be thrilled with a movie these days. Thrilled in the sense that the film not only has great acting but the storyline, simple as it maybe, is so engaging, and moving, that you can't help but be affected. You're invited into the lives of two individuals and you want to try and understand why it doesn't work out. After all, living in the United States, where half of all marriages end in divorce, how many young couples make the right decision to marry?Does anyone in the world remember Juno?  The most overrated piece of tripe I've ever seen. And you recall how ridiculous the entire abortion sequence was?Then you go see a film like Blue Valentine, and suddenly you are brought back down to REALITY, and you witness how painful an experience an abortion can be and with it (even an abortive attempt), you physically feel the emotional spikes of both individuals and you say to yourself, is this a movie? Or is this actually a couple somewhere in a small town in Pennsylvania today going through the exact same experience, right now?Yes, Gosling and Williams brilliantly capture their characters raison d'etre for living and it's difficult to lay blame on either of them when trying to come to terms with the dissolution of their relationship. In some ways, I was more upset at Williams character because she shows her true colors by marrying Gosling's character even though it's very questionable how much she truly loved him. Ultimately, you come away with the conclusion that she married him because of her unwanted pregnancy.Goesling's character doesn't possess ambition. He's satisfied with the status-quo and his lot in life. He's a painter, with a daughter, and a wife whom he adores. What is there to complain about??But the human story is one of pathos and ecstasy. We just aren't a boring species, folks. And this film carefully mines its way through the emotional lives of this couple using careful flashback sequences to show how some of us start in life but evolve later to recognize the deception of our own decisions and are then frustrated when we can't have our beginning back again.I can't recommend this film enough, especially if you want to a good cry! Crying is so cathartic, folks!  It's good for the soul to cry every once in a blue moon. And it's a crying for the loss of love. I've met some individuals in life who are not lucky in love, have not found their soul mate. These people are successful in other ways but not in love. Love captures our emotional imagination like nothing else. And Blue Valentine reminds us just how fragile each and everyone of us are. The saying, better to love, than to never have loved at all rings true. But oh what a painful experience it can be.

reviewText: In a time in which young audiences' idea of great entertainment appears to be movies that are flashy, violent, or with lack of social values, it is quite a risk to do a serious drama, a simple film about the human condition as is, about real families and real issues that affect today' society. Derek Cianfrance's "Blue Valentine," is an intense and unforgettable film that will make you value or re-examine your life.The film stars Ryan Gosling as Dean, and Michelle Williams as Cindy, a married couple with a young daughter, Frankie (Faith Wladyka), and it begins when they have been together for a while. However, we immediately can feel that things are not well between them, that they are in a crisis period. They are working class parents - she is a nurse, he works in a packing and moving company -, and are on a daily struggle to live the American dream. Life goes on until Cindy accidentally meets Bobby (Mike Vogel), an ex-boyfriend, while doing grocery shopping. Nothing happens then, but when Cindy tells Dean about it, it sparks bad memories that will create great friction in the already-troubled marriage. Indeed, we are then taken to the past, when Cindy was dating her then boyfriend Bobby, and how she eventually meets Dean. We realize that both their families were dysfunctional, which in part shaped their future. From then on the movie goes back and forth, until we are taken to the dramatic end."Blue Valentine" is crude in almost every sense of the word, including sex - real life at its best. It is a penetrating story about disintegration, which can happen to any of us, and how the past sometimes haunts the present. Both Gosling and Williams are superb, and they act their evolution as a married couple to perfection. The photography by Andrij Parekh greatly supports the story, and Williams deservedly received an Academy Award Nomination for Best Actress. The Blu-ray edition includes audio commentaries by director Derek Cianfrance and co-editor Jim Helton, a making-of documentary, deleted scenes, and more. (USA, 2010, 112 mins plus additional materials)Exclusively reviewed on May 9, 2011 by Eric Gonzalez for Anchor Bay Entertainment.

reviewText: "Blue Valentine" is about as perfect a film as any you're likely to see. Even with the recent release of the brilliant "Rabbit Hole," it's been ages since I've seen a story so resonant with characters so real. Many wonderful films have taken life issues and heightened them for dramatic emphasis; this movie presents itself so authentically that, if it weren't for the casting of Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams, I might have mistaken it for a work of creative nonfiction. We're often asked to look deeper into characters and find a little bit of ourselves. Here, we not only see ourselves, but also just about everyone we know or have known. This is a human story - so simple and yet so complex, full of drama and humor, mindful of the situation yet vague with the answers. It taps into our emotions and somehow finds the right one to play off of, no matter what our circumstances in life.Gosling and Williams play Dean and Cindy. The film shifts back and forth through time, showing two distinct phases in their relationship. In the beginning, Cindy was in college studying medicine and Dean was an employee for a moving van company. They didn't have much in common, except that they were in love. They're now married, and although they're raising an adorable daughter, Frankie (Faith Wladyka), that spark is no longer there. Cindy is a full time nurse and hardly ever home. Dean misses his wife to the point that he drinks a bit more than he should. They snap at each other when it seems as if nothing is wrong. Neither of them are bad people; it's just that, somewhere along the way, they've lost the ability to communicate with one another. Dean tries to rekindle the flame by taking Cindy to a motel and having a night to themselves. It doesn't go as planned.What went wrong? It would be far too easy to place the blame on an emotional catastrophe, like an affair or a death. Maybe they're just incompatible. Cindy's goal is to become a doctor, which is to say she wants to make something of herself. To make something of yourself is by definition a change, and change is a sign that you're not happy with the way things are. If you watched as your mother had all the motivation and contentment bullied out of her by your father, would you be happy? Cindy was close with her grandmother (Jen Jones), who told her that, in spite of her marriage to her grandfather, she never really fell in love. So Cindy has two generations worth of evidence to support the belief that the word "commitment" is code for settling for something less.Compare this to Dean. He lives authentically. He never graduated high school because it just wasn't for him. When he was younger, he was certain he'd never want a wife or a child; now that he's older, he realizes that he always wanted both. For him, work is not about building a career but about providing for himself and his family, and he's content to take whatever odd jobs he can get. In essence, he likes himself the way he is. I suspect Cindy was more attracted to an ideal rather than a person. In those early days, it was fun dating a man with no prospects. Now that they're married, now that it's obvious that Dean has no ambition to be anyone other than himself, she sees only the wasted potential. What about his music? What about his singing? It makes no sense to her that he can enjoy those things yet not use them as a way to become something greater.Inevitably, it comes down the child. By wanting a divorce, Dean claims that Cindy isn't thinking of what's best for their daughter. He argues (perhaps correctly) that Frankie shouldn't have to grow up in a broken home, as he did. Cindy argues (perhaps correctly) that Frankie shouldn't have to grow up listening to her parents fight, as she did. I will not use this review as a platform for my views on parental rights or child advocacy. All that matters is that the issue is presented realistically, and that there are no easy answers.A subplot involving an ex-boyfriend (Mike Vogel) might seem downplayed but is in fact as intelligently written as the rest of the film is. In another life - in another movie - he would be the kind of guy that sits on the witness stand with his head down, sobbing to the jury about loving her too much. Thank God this movie doesn't go for anything that contrived. It's a cliché to say that a film is a slice of life, but in this case, that's the best description there is. "Blue Valentine" has no agenda; what we personally bring to the movie determines how we view the characters, which is to say we're not forced to come to conclusions about how we feel about them. They are who they are. This is the kind of movie that may not have stunts or special effects but can still grab you and not let go. You should see it. Then you should ask your family to see it. Then you should ask your friends to see it, but only on the condition that they ask their families to see it.

reviewText: Blue Valentine chronicles the relationship between Dean (Ryan Gosling) and Cindy (Michelle Williams) and portrays the all-too-realistic pain and anger that can come hand in hand with falling in love. Cindy is a quirky blonde who had fallen for the typical high-school jock character before Dean turned up with his ukulele, serenading her with the apt song 'You always hurt the ones you love'. The film switches between these early scenes of passionate attraction to the bleak final days of their relationship: stuck in a dead end job, Dean drinks and struggles with his anger as Cindy tries to balance her job, her daughter and her relationship.Gosling and Williams act the parts faultlessly and I was completely captivated by the characters as they fell in love with each other, and cried with them as it all fell apart. It is a deeply painful and endearing love story and it is almost relentlessly grim, so anyone hoping for a happy ending will probably want to give this one a miss. My only criticism would be that the story jumps from the captivating scenes of the couple falling in love to the brutal breakdown of their marriage without sufficiently showing how it got to that state. As a result, sympathy tends to fall with the loveable but slightly useless character of Dean, as he is neglected and snapped at by Cindy and yet the film seems to want to give the impression that each are mutually hurt and responsible for the failure of the relationship.

reviewText: Blue Valentine is a film designed to stir debate, but not in the usual silly political nor emotional sort of way. Its debate is of a deeper and more profound measure, and that is it asks which of the two main characters profiled in the film is in the wrong? The film does its best to be evenhanded, and for every tick of the ledger against one of the major characters, an equally incisive demerit can be handed out to the other. However, the biggest demerit I can give regarding this 2010 film, directed by Derek Cianfrance, about the turmoil of a mediocre marriage, is the critical cribbing that abounds in essays and reviews of the film, online and off. And that cribbing involves the almost near-universal claim that this film follows the end of, or the dissolution of, that marriage. Yet, nothing of the sort can be convincingly construed from the film's contents nor its ending.Yes, the film, which bifurcates into flashbacks of how the married couple of Dean and Cindy Pereira met, and details a troubling two days, some years later, around the 4th of July, does have Cindy declare that she wants a divorce, but that occurs 15-20 minutes before the film ends, with Dean walking away, down a street, after some reconciliation has occurred. Also, given the volume of detail that we get on this couple's relationship, from the things actually shown in the two time frames, to those things easily inferred from those seen things, and the character portrayals of the two lead actors, Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams, it's pretty obvious that, like most couples in this sort of relationship between two weak willed individuals, this run of troubling days is simply the latest incarnation of personal melodrama the two have jointly constructed, in fact, enhancing their bond, long term, due to its joint effort. And the film reinforces this with a few telling moments in the film wherein we see Cindy's parents' marriage, and hear of the marriage of her grandmother- two women Cindy clearly resembles; especially as she seeks Dean to be violent toward her, only to belittle him as `not a man' because he refuses her invitations to be brutish. In short, this is not a film about the end of a marriage, but a film about 99+% of all marriages that last till death do us part.

reviewText: Derek Cianfrance's BLUE VALENTINE is a disturbing look at emotional decay.  It chronicles the relationship of two young lovers, Dean and Cindy, who marry and have a child.  The film goes back and forth in time, beautifully painting a full portrait of this passionate, troubled relationship, which ultimately descends into emotionally violent chaos.As the leads, Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams shine.  Neither is a true saint here; they are human beings, and this is a human relationship.  The actors have amazing chemistry: the early years are genuinely moving, and the later years are genuinely disturbing.  The script is stellar, the directing is top-notch, the camera work is engaging (you really feel like a part of the movie), but it is the performances of the lead actors that anchor this film in reality.You should be warned: this isn't an easy film to watch.  There's not a whole lot of physical violence (just one scene, and it's not what you may be expecting), and the sexuality is more hinted at than anything (who the hell wanted to give this an NC-17 rating, and why?).  But the emotions, the tension, the hurt these two (un)intentionally inflict on each other...when contrasted against the spontaneous love of their early years, it's powerful.  And that is what makes this such a memorable film.  Portraits of relationships fail all the time, because they become stereotypical or boring.  BLUE VALENTINE is neither.

reviewText: "Blue Valentine" profiles the relationship of a young couple whose marriage is on the verge of imploding, while simultaneously flashing back to the beginning of their relationship. This allows the film to explore how the very differences that attract two people to one another initially can become the same differences that eventually make a relationship unbearable.Cindy is a focused, dutiful, practical medical student. Dean is an impulsive, emotional blue collar worker. The flashbacks of the film show how the two meet, and, due to an unplanned pregnancy, quickly decide to marry and start a family. The flashback scenes make it incredibly obvious why these two people would fall in love: Dean offers Cindy spontaneity and romance. Cindy offers Dean stability and purpose.The scenes that take place in the present, 6 years after they meet, make it incredibly obvious why these two people would be unable to sustain a relationship, especially while raising a child. Dean just wants to be a husband and father, and enjoys the freedom of working a blue collar job where he can "drink a beer at 8 o'clock in the morning." Cindy takes her nursing career seriously, and makes it clear that she resents having to be the disciplinarian to their daughter, while Dean gets to be the playful, fun dad. Sensing they're on the verge of disaster as a couple, Dean tries to arrange an overnight stay at a cheesy theme hotel. Sadly, his plan backfires, and the couple's relationship finally implodes when Cindy refuses Dean what he needs the most (emotional and sexual intimacy), and Dean, in a drunken rage, threatens what's most important to Cindy (meaningful work and security).The film offers intimacy in a way that few films ever do. Not only are all the facets of the film's central relationship depicted in incredibly intimate detail, even the tangential relationships all maintain a level of intimacy, even if the screen time is limited (Dean's relationship with his daughter; Cindy's relationship with her ailing grandmother; Dean's relationship with an older co-worker; Cindy's relationship with her ex-boyfriend). The film is beautifully directed, written, edited, and shot. And the two leads are outstanding. It's wonderful to see two actors paired together who not only have chemistry but are equally matched in talent, intelligence, and commitment to their roles.

reviewText: "Maybe I've just seen too many movies," says Dean. And, maybe I have also ... because, for all its efforts, Blue Valentine failed to hold my attention.Foremost, I applaud the director for making an emotionally complex film. Too many filmmakers cater to the expectations of the masses (which is why we have a glut of "relationship" films that all follow the same formula. Boring.) Likewise, I do appreciate the aesthetics of this piece. A palette of red, white, and blue is an appropriate choice for this thoroughly American story. Similarly, the choice of blue lighting in the Future Room emphasizes the coldness of this rapidly destructing marriage. And, while many film-goers will find the non-linear structure the film to be confusing, it seems a clever choice (for the happier days to be told in reflection). Moreover, I did "like" how a simple encounter at the liquor store turns into an ugly car-ride ... I "like" how the audience interprets this moment as a wild over-reaction and is later proven so very wrong.Nonetheless, the story itself had some (unintentional) deep flaws in rhythm. In fact, the darkness of the film may not be at the crux of these negative reviews. Plenty of people appreciate even darker films (such as anything by Aronofsky) without a single complaint. In the same vein, smart audiences do not require "good guys" and "bad guys." They don't need a husband who batters his wife (or a wife who has an affair)to support a divorce. Gray characters have become a welcome "norm." So, while it's easy to point to these qualities and say, "Well, the audience just isn't sophisticated enough to understand this film," that's not entirely true. For me, I found the tempo so inconsistent that I had difficulty remaining engaged. Simple as that.With this said, this film has garnered the attention of many fine critics and scholars. There is "something" here that definitely appeals to a number of people. Therefore, I vote that you rent this work and decide for yourself. It may be a piece you need to see ...  Gosling holds up a card in the end-credits that reads, "Is this you?". If it is, maybe you NEED this film. Maybe it will make you feel less alone. If you do rent this, I highly encourage you to watch the end credits which show snapshots from happier times. It is (for me) the most poignant aspect of the film.

reviewText: This is the finest American film of the last few years.  With a superb soundtrack ('You and Me' by Penny and the Quarters) and two powerful acting performances that are as good as you'll see, this is a movie that should not be missed.  The story line differs from most romance films in that it portrays some of the harsh realities not unlikely to ensue after the credits roll in every other popcorn romance movie.What makes this film unique is that it consistently documents the juxtaposition between the giddy highs of the initial infatuation period versus six years down the road when mundane frustrations set in after the romance has long ago evaporated.  Another interesting aspect is the way in which it portrays the stresses and harsh realities of the 9 to 5 work environment.  Too often in many films it's as if the characters exist completely outside a reality in which 95% of Americans slave away in; Blue Valentine doesn't fail to intelligently tie into the script the trials and tribulations of the every day work world.In an outlandish move the ratings board originally gave Blue Valentine an NC-17, but then in a peculiar twist later gave it a more reasonable R without the director having made a single cut.Hopefully potential audiences won't overlook this outstanding movie since it's a relatively low budget indie film and clearly doesn't have the advertising budget that the giant studios lavish on their mass produced drivel.  This is both a fascinating and devastating piece of work.

reviewText: Filmmaker Derek Cianfrance shows a certain audacity in giving the viewer his dark, sad-eyed 2010 relationship drama a beginning and an ending without providing a linear narrative to bring it together into a more predictably episodic account. Thanks to engrossing performances from Ryan Gosling (The Ides of March) and Michelle Williams (My Week with Marilyn) and an insightful screenplay co-written by Cianfrance, Joey Curtis and Cami Delavigne, the middle passage doesn't feel missing. Instead, the two parts almost evoke an unsettling memory piece where a couple goes through the enthrallment of falling in love and the purgatory of knowing when that love has died a painful death. Granted the film is not easy to watch at times, but it feels bracingly honest in its portrayal of a marriage unraveling from the weight of social class differences that irreparably breach the relationship at the core.The story focuses on a young working-class couple, Dean Pereira and Cindy Heller. At the outset, he's a high school dropout working for a moving company, and she's a pre-med student living with her unhappy parents and caring for her grandmother in Pennsylvania. They have a chance encounter, fall breathlessly in love, and rush into marriage when Cindy finds herself pregnant by her previous boyfriend, a bad-tempered wrestler named Bobby. Dean agrees to raise Cindy's daughter Frankie, as his own, and their familial bond is established. Several years later near the end of their marriage, they are living in rural Pennsylvania. Dean paints houses for a living, while Cindy has become a nurse. Going through the motions of their marriage, they make one last desperate attempt at resurrecting their troubled relationship by going to a "sex" motel, but a domestic dispute ensues leading to a morning-after altercation between Dean and the doctor who had called Cindy to come into the clinic to work that morning. When Dean cannot contain his anger and disappointment, their marriage becomes irreparably broken.The shifting back and forth in time between Dean and Cindy's courtship and the dissolution of their predictable marriage provides a prime opportunity for the actors to show the subtle and often visceral ways the characters had changed over the course of six years. While the scenes of their younger selves are filled with romance and welcome humor in the midst of their sometimes overwhelming bleakness, it is painful and moving to watch the motel scenes where the pair loses the last remaining threads holding them together. Gosling and Williams apparently improvised much of their dialogue, especially in the courtship scenes, and they calibrate their performances with a rhythm and texture that makes their perpetually volatile relationship feel real and heartbreaking. With the use of a Super 16mm in the early scenes and a Red One in the later ones, cinematographer Andrij Parekh lends a palpable authenticity to the characters' lower-middle-class lives. It's worthwhile viewing if only for the lead actors' stellar work.
summary: Relentless Portrait of the Beginning and the End of a Conflicted Relationship

reviewText: In some ways BLUE VALENTINE is two films. On the one hand is a naturalistic look at what happens when a relationship breaks down. On the other (told in flashback) it's a sort of quirky romantic comedy that tells the well-worn story of kooky, lost girl finds equally lost guy: together they compliment each other and live happily ever after... except in this case we know they don't.And that's essentially what's wrong with the film. It's a clash of ideas but writer/director Derek Cianfrance can't resolve that clash in any meaningful way.By definition rom-coms are a type of wish fulfilment fantasy (think of something like LOVE ACTUALLY - where the PM falls for the tea girl). They work perfectly within their own context but held up to realistic analysis fail dismally. And it's the naturalism of the second strand that forces the viewer to consider the whole realistically. I was left utterly confused as to what I was watching. Or how I was supposed to.Although the acting is first-rate, this is also a deeply uncomfortable film to sit through. The rawness of the split up was too much for me. Add in some gratuitous sex scenes and implausibilities (if an ex-boyfriend of mine asked if I was unfaithful to my husband I'd be deeply offended not coquettish) and the result is a film that fails to convince or engage.I suppose BLUE VALENTINE wants its cake and to eat it too. It might have worked well either as an off-beat romantic comedy or as a serious drama, but by combining the two it fails at both.

reviewText: Roger Ebert once wrote of a movie that it was like going on a long trip with the Bickersons.  "Blue Valentine," is sort of like spending two hours with the Saturday Night Live characters, The Needlers, a.k.a. the Couple Who Should Be Divorced.  It's a brutally honest and authentic look at a dissolving marriage, as well as a good movie, but you may have moments where you're tempted to hit the Mute button.  Critics described this as "haunting" and "powerful," and I fully agree.  But it's a movie I found painful to watch (because of the authenticity), and I don't think I'll ever see it again. It's easier to enjoy depressing movies if there's at least a tiny ray of hope present.Ryan Gosling who plays Dean, and Michelle Williams who plays Cindy, do an outstanding job of getting under the skin of their characters.  (Actually, I haven't seen them in anything where they did a poor job.)  All the characters behave like real people and not Hollywood ones.  When the mom fixes breakfast for her daughter on a weekday, she gives her a bowl of (mediocre) oatmeal, not a five-star gourmet spread, and the kid refuses to eat it.  This is not supposed to be proof that Cindy is a horrible mom, just frazzled.  When the grandmother is through being read a bedtime story, she sits up and demands a cigarette. When characters are asked a difficult question, they may actually respond with, "I don't know," not some rapid-fire witty repartee that the scriptwriters spend hours getting just right.The movie starts out with Dean and Cindy as a middle-aged couple with a young child.  They have various issues which will be familiar to anyone in that situation.  In an attempt to rekindle their romance, Dean persuades Cindy to spend the night a motel.  We then get flashbacks of how they met and their lives leading up to the present.  They fight a lot.  They make up.  They have unsatisfying sexual experiences.  They fight some more.  There's absolutely no attempt to make any of this charming in the manner of a Hollywood romantic comedy.  That's why it's hard to watch.  But it will probably stay with you after you finish watching it.
summary: Honest, moving, but hard to watch

reviewText: This film opens with an idyllic scene of family life in a middle working class home, in a small town or rural setting in Pennsylvania. A young girl is shown playing in the yard, waiting for her dog to return. She sings and talks to herself, having a great time as children around ages 4 or 5 often do when they entertain themselves playing alone. She lookes for her dad, who is doting and loving, he reassures her their dog will return. They search in the backyard, look in his outdoor cage and doghouse. He is not there. This portion of the film is so well done, that it seems like a homemade movie or video of real life. The dad and daughter go upstairs, awaken the mom from a good sleep. She would rather have remained sleeping but ends up making breakfast, helping her daughter to dress for shcool and makes plans to go to her school recital later that day. It seems like a typical day for this family. However, there is just enough normalcy to make the viewer wonder, is it real or not?The mom and dad arrive separately at their daughter's grammar school for the program. Cindy is tearful and Dean asks "what's wrong?" She does not explain. Outside the school, Dean and Cindy briefly talk and make plans for a "date night". They explain to their daughter she will be staying overnight at her grandpa's house. She raises no objections and the stage is set for the exploration of unknown possibilties, peaking this viewer's interest and creating anticipation for what will happen next. This film is exceptional in how it captures the natural behaviors and emotions of the characters, leaving the viewer to wonder and question, where is this all going. Cindy prepares for their night out by shopping for liquor and accidentally meets a former boyfriend who was a serious old flame in the past. He asks if she is married, she replies "yes".  He replies, "Lucky guy." Next he asks, "Are you faithful?" She expresses surprise at the question and answers, "Yes, I have been." When Cindy tells Dean about meeting him by chance, she downplays the encounter, describing him as fat, to which Dean becomes angry and defensive. Dean's outburst at what seems like an innocent description by Cindy, reveals  his smoldering, up to this point unexpressed true emotions. The film is developing an edge that takes the viewer by surprise but which is a welcome development in the plot.Dean had rented the "futuristic room" at a local hotel; it looks like a motor home that was made into a hotel. The space is cramped but it is well designed, with a revolving bed, a wall behind the bed has an enlarged photo of earth from space. The honesty and realism in the film are palpable in how Dean and Cindy prepare for their special, intimate night out together. As they engage in adult behaviors, there are flashbacks to when they met, when their romance was new, exciting and they were a young couple in love. The flashbacks are in stark contrast to their current, cool, emotionally distant and withdrawn state. The passion of the past is so joyous, spontaneous and natural, that their current lack of emotional connection and fake intimacy becomes even more obvious.In this films there is a gradual crescendo of feelings and events which is highly satisfying. At times, the camera provides long and close shots of the characters revealing amazing acting. The story of the past, how this couple met, became interested in each other, built a committed relationship and married contrasts with their current life, filled with tensions and serious communication deficits. I am very surprised by Dean's immaturity, since in the beginning he seemed to have so much self control. He naturally took the lead in winning over Cindy's love and trust. I will not give away the ending but the viewer must decide at this point, whether or not I provided enough information to make viewing this film worthwhile. In my estimation it is a good film but I will deduct one star because at times it left me with a strong impression that both Dean and Cindy were working waaaaaaay to hard at expressing their emotions, in other words they "over acted" their parts. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

But shortly after that incident you have a flash back of how Dean returns to the nursing home to give the old man a locket and bumps into her. The two accidental bump into each other and spend the rest of the night together. They end the night as well with a love making session.Of course Cynthia ends up pregnant. And you are left wondering who the father could be? You say to yourself, well obviously its Dean's because they are married. Right?! Wrong. Its Cynthia's previous boyfriend who she dumps because of the "accident they had during lovemaking" and the guy NEVER knows he has a daughter. So Cynthia travels to NY where she tells Dean she's pregnant and tells him that its unlikely his. Nonetheless Dean accompanies her to get an abortion where you learn she's had 25 sexual partners beginning at 13 years of age. After going through the steps of prepping for the abortion (gurney straps and all) she changes her mind. Dean, rises to the occasion to be the father to another man's child, even after the real father jumps him because he thinks Dean just came between him and his girl.Don't get me wrong, you can see the socio-economic differences are obviously going to play a role in the ultimate undoing of this marriage. Cynthia is a college student (aspiring Medical Student who obviously becomes frustrated by the reality that she only becomes a nurse as opposed to a practicing doctor. Although dysfunctional and obviously playing a role in her emotional voidness, she does come from a middle income home in a nice suburban street. Dean on the other hand is a high school drop out from a broken home (his mother has walked out on him when he was 10) and views as being Cynthia's husband and their daughter's father as his greatest accomplishment. He also has a drinking problem that plays a role in their unraveling. To me the irony was that the person who seemed to have the most to offer in the relationship is the one that is less emotionally giving or able to give because of her surmounting issues. At the end of the film Cynthia tells Dean "I have nothing left to give you" and the truth is I was left wondering what exactly did you give in the first place? In the end I felt horrible for Dean. Jumping in to save this girl's honor, raise a child that wasn't his and in the very end what is he left with? Nothing. Nothing, yet he walks away never throwing in Cynthia's face all that he's done for her in terms of being that male role. But again, I was left wondering, what next? Does Frankie (their daughter) ever find out who her real dad is? Does Cynthia ever call her ex (during one scene in the movie she bumps into him in a liquor store). I really feel this movie culminated to an end right when I was at my angriest. Again, as a woman, I just find it so difficult to relate to Cynthia. As a PERSON I find it difficult to relate to her. And while you can argue she is a product of her emotionally empty and abusive environment (there is one scene where her father explodes at her mom over what she's made for dinner)....You still can't sympathize (at least I couldn't) with Cynthia's actions and lack of gratitude for a man who stepped into a relationship with her knowing all the baggage she was bringing to the table. Knowing that he would be essentially caring for a child that wasn't his biologically. To me her frustration is unfounded once the story unfolds and all the skeletons are revealed.It's still a brilliantly acted movie and if I took away 2 stars it was because I was just angered by one of the main characters. It is definitely a movie that allows you to reflect....it beckons you to reflect to make sense of why it ends the way it does.

reviewText: Nonlinear storytelling, whether in a novel or a film, challenges the reader/viewer with fragments of story scattered across time and coincidences in a way that can create disorientation: the payback is that this technique of relating a story allows an intimate examination of  not only the characters of the tale but also an opportunity to turn the events inward, perhaps reviving memories, piecing together reasons for the present and the journey taken simultaneously with the development of the story.  Director Derek Cianfrance (a young writer, cinematographer and director of remarkable skill) worked with Cami Delavigne and Joey Curtis to develop this examination of a dismembering relationship that probably should have never begun. And while the story per se takes place in a 24 hour period, it exposes all the cracks and interstices that have created the breaking point in their marriage by flashbacks that often seem to flow with the story at hand.Dean Pereira (Ryan Gosling) is a house painter whose motivation to work is to be married to Cindy Heller Pereira (Michelle Williams), an ultrasound technician for Dr. Feinberg (Ben Shenkman), and their daughter Frankie (Faith Waldyka). Dean was a high school dropout without a stable family history and therefore not interested in marriage or family: Cindy's family was also dysfunctional but she had a closeness to her grandmother who encouraged her dreams of becoming a doctor.  Dean meets Cindy and his dreams change - he wants to do anything to be with her. Cindy's motivations altered when she became pregnant, not knowing whether the father was Dean or her other passionate flame Bobby (Mike Vogel).  Dean is supportive and loves Cindy to the point that despite the paternity question he marries Cindy.  With that much of a past given to us in snippets we begin the story on a routine day- Dean has grown scruffy and needs a drink to get his day going and would rather play with Frankie than work at his low paying job, while Cindy runs the motor that keeps the home afloat, dashing off to practice her craft. Two incidents occur: Cindy encounters Bobby at a liquor store and a flame simmers while Dean leaves a gate open a home that leads to the loss of heir pet animal. Both are tense and Dean makes a reservation to spend the night in a motel love nest - not Cindy's idea of romance. reviewText: There are some films that manage to simultaneously warm the hearts of moviegoers and break them. "Blue Valentine," the first major film from writer/director Derek Cianfrance, plays tug of war with your heart for its entire running length. It is a stunning debut from Cianfrance that takes a familiar tune and strips it down to its most raw and unflinching form. This is a film that lives and breathes, as we experience the flames of love being extinguished before our very eyes by the harsh realities of life."Blue Valentine" stars Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams, two of Hollywood's most talented and courageous actors, in a very low-budgeted, non-Hollywood film that centers on the rise and fall of a young couple's relationship, as they fall out of love after years of marriage.The film begins in the present, and then skips back and forth through time, showing the young couple at two different times in their relationship, from first time that they met to their now doomed and dissolving marriage. Structurally, this can sometimes be a distracting and confusing ploy to make a story of falling romance seem more interesting than it is. That is not the case here, and the film is wonderfully edited.Gosling plays Dean, once a childish but devoted guy who has no big plans for the future except to keep on living each day, waiting for whatever the world has in store for him. He is a nice guy, but as the films reverts the present, we see that being a nice guy is not enough to sustain a happy marriage.Dean's tendency to sit back and be content eventually becomes too much for Cindy (Williams) to deal with. She is a charismatic girl in the beginning who wants to be a doctor one day. When she meets Dean for the first time in the nursing home where her grandmother lives, and where Dean, working for a moving company, is moving in an elderly man, their eyes connect. In that moment, the two actors make us believe that this is something special.These scenes in the past are so wonderfully acted, as the nave and passionate lovers connect and embrace, make love and share each other's dreams.  These passages in the film make it all the more painful when we are reminded of the present, where the passion and honesty are dissolving at a rapid pace. They also have a daughter named Frankie (Faith Wladyka) who was not planned, but who is accepted and loved deeply by her feuding parents.Told in a linear fashion, I think "Blue Valentine" would lose a lot of its substance. The big question of what went wrong is never explicitly answered, and I am not certain there is one answer. There is so much authenticity and power in the performances, particularly Williams, who does the most challenging and brilliant work of her career. To pull off the small jump in age (10 or 15 years) that she and Gosling perform effortlessly here seem like it would be incredibly difficult. We are so emotionally invested in Dean and Cindy's lives that we don't doubt it for a second."Blue Valentine" stirred up quite a controversy in the movie world when it initially earned an NC-17 rating from the MPAA for a scene of explicit sexuality. After a successful petition, the rating was rightfully dropped to an R. It's a silly thought that in our society, movies like "Piranha 3D" and "Saw" that contain such gratuitous violence can pass with R-ratings, but as for sexuality (GOD, LET IT NOT BE SO!) there is so little tolerance to spare.This film is a work of art that realizes that in life, there are few easy paths to take. Many questions go unanswered and many days pass unremarkably. From what I have come to understand, the method by which Cianfrance and the two stars handled the material was through much improvisation, which allows for spontaneity and authenticity if handled well. Williams and Gosling are so astonishingly intense and real in this movie that at times it is difficult to watch.But those who can stomach the searing performances will experience a tremendous story of found and lost romance, and one of the best films of 2010.GRADE: A

reviewText: To put it simply, Blue Valentine tells a modern love story of the birth and death of a modern relationship. The film acts as a window through which to view this relationship and see the conflicting ideas and personalities that once brought two people together but now drive them apart. Relying heavily on improvisation, the success of the film rests with its two leads and rarely have I seen actors pour their heart and soul into their performances the way Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams have here. There's a lot of raw emotion on display, yet there are no cheap theatrics nor is anything over-sentimentalized. It's a rare movie about love and marriage that may strike a little too close to home for some viewers.The story cross-cuts between two different time periods, but begins with introducing us to a working-class married couple named Dean (Gosling) and Cindy (Williams), and their young daughter Frankie. Dean is a house-painter and a dedicated, hands-on father who has settled comfortably into his marriage and his working-class existence. Cindy is a nurse whom we can tell from only body language has outgrown Dean, but Dean seems either unaware or unable to accept it. In an attempt to reignite the passion, Dean makes a reservation at a cheesy sex motel (in the Future Room). These present-day scenes are shot on RED, a digital camera that gives the film a monotonous, dull color palette, but a more intimate feel. The early scenes are shot on Super 16MM and make the scenes feel much brighter and more alive. This technique remarkably contrasts the more idealistic beginning with the cold, hard reality of the end. Frequent use of a hand-held camera makes these scenes feel much more personal. In the early scenes, Dean works for a moving company and meets Cindy at a retirement home, where she's visiting her grandmother. Subtle physical changes are employed to show Dean and Cindy at these different, but relatively close ages.Director and co-writer Derek Cianfrance doesn't play with the chronology of the story as a gimmick, but as a way to toy with our emotions. An example takes place in the Future Room when Dean puts on a song and tries to dance with Cindy. It's clear that this scene is where Dean really becomes aware of how disconnected Cindy is from him, but we don't think much about the music. Later in the film, but taking place earlier, we see Dean playing Cindy the song for the first time and we see the romantic significance it has for them. If Cianfrance had told his story in chronological order, this latter scene would be a happy moment but in showing us later we sadly realize how far this relationship has progressed downward. Cianfrance spent years trying to finance this project and his directorial talent is made clear. His raw, loose, and revealing style recalls the work of John Cassavetes but he's not just an imitation of talent. He's very adept at framing his shots to achieve the maximum emotional effect possible and must be given credit for directing two actor's to give some of the most soul-shattering performances I've seen recently.Not to downplay what a depressing film this is, but if you're expecting an emotional powerhouse of a film with a lot of yelling, screaming, Oscar-baiting performances you'll be surprised. The film maintains an understated realism throughout; not every argument escalates into a shouting match, not every significant moment is heightened in Hollywood-fashion to show that it means something, and the character's never spout off any wooden lines of dialogue to explain what we can already see happening. Compare and contrast Dean and Cindy's relationship with the strained relationship portrayed in another terrific 2010 filmRabbit Holeand you will see how understated this film is. Even Dean's first encounter with Cindy, while cute and charming, is as understated as every scene before it when, in a lesser film it would be written and filmed to be a more dramatic, profound moment in the lives of the characters. You rarely meet the one you love under extraordinary, theatrical circumstances. Dean and Cindy never feel like characters trapped in a doomed Hollywood romance. They're vulnerable, sensitive, and normal people who can't allow their emotions to go unrestrained any longer. It's heartbreaking stuff, but it never exploits the two nor does it make any attempts to obscure their flaws. With that said, much of the film's impact stems from how you relate and apply the characters' struggles to your own life.Dean is the more sympathetic character of the two and many will leave thinking negatively of Cindy, but I found it easier to empathize with her as the film progressed. The film shows only the birth and the death of the relationship and we are never told what exactly went wrong. This may bother some people, but I found this to be one of the more poignant aspects of the film. How many can remember a relationship from the beginning, through the middle, and to the end? In life, we usually cut out the middle too. We see the end of a marriage that is without passion and, in Cindy's case, love but nothing seems particularly...wrong. Dean drinks often, but isn't portrayed as an alcoholic and he's a very involved father. It seems that Cindy just gets bored and, yet I did sympathize with her because of how well Williams conveyed Cindy's feelings, especially the toll that mental exhaustion has taken on her plight.Michelle Williams received an Oscar nomination, but Ryan Gosling did not. Gosling gives the kind of performance where an actor immerses themselves so deeply into the material that the actor disappears and the character takes over. Gosling captures every nuance playing the decidedly average guy Dean so perfectly. It's a performance that taps into some very dark emotions and never seems more dramatic than necessary. Gosling could've chewed the scenery with this role, but he just plays it real. Few performances are more capable of breaking your heart than this. Williams opens herself completely to her character and portrays a woman trudging through a marriage that she's long given up on for no discernible reason other than she has outgrown Dean. Cindy is a selfish character, only sympathetic as someone who must escape the confines of her marriage rather than suffer for the rest of her life the way her parents did. There's not a line of dialogue that makes Cindy more sympathetic, yet I didn't hate her at the end of the film just because of how Williams carried this role. Cindy is not so much a selfish woman, as a lost one who can conceal her emotional disdain for her life and marriage no more. It's a compelling performance, that relies heavily on body language but I feel like Gosling was robbed of a nomination.The improvisational nature of the film is very useful and helps tell this story with more realism than any script could. The dialogue especially feels so loose and natural you know it couldn't be written. One example of how the improvisation works so well is the scene that was most prevalent in the trailer and is, in my opinion, the most remarkable scene in the film. Dean plays a ukulele and sings, while Cindy dances. This is such a beautiful scene that expresses so much about the characters at this stage in their life. In this moment, there's such freedom and a very subtle poignancy. It is so romantic in its simplistic way, it makes the relationship seem so much more real and seeing it end so much more tragic.Much attention came to the film when the MPAA slapped it with an NC-17 rating, only to give it an `R' rating on appeal with no cuts being made. The sex scenes are not particularly graphic, far from gratuitous, and in no way erotic. Sex has rarely been used as effectively onscreen to illustrate a total loss of passion in a relationship, as well as contrasting something that was once pleasurable and is now devoid of meaning. I think the MPAA was more frightened by the emotional power of these scenes than they were of any of the physical intimacy.Blue Valentine is not an easy film to digest and some will dismiss it as emotional, depressing, and pointless fodder. It's not a happy film nor is it a film that gives easy answers to tough questions about modern relationships. In life, many things don't turn out happy and many questions are left unanswered. The ending may not satisfy viewers, but I found the stunning end credits served as an epilogue almost and, if not, certainly a eulogy. It's a special, powerful film with both realism and a sense of irony (it's ironic that the Future Room is where it becomes clear that Dean and Cindy's marriage has no future) and a film that I have a hard time putting out of my mind. Ultimately, it's a revealing look at modern love and the film's intimacy and willingness to plunge the depths of this subject make it an experience of unusual depth and perception. While it's hard to enjoy Blue Valentine, I loved Blue Valentine.GRADE: A

He is moving Walter, a really frail 90-something-year-old man, into a nursing home where Cindy's grandmother lives. That's how they meet and Dean falls in love. A major revelation of this scene is how tender-hearted Dean is toward Walter. He unpacks his things and sets them up so that Walter leaves one abode and right into a new one with all his familiar things around him, hopefully erasing any feeling of dislocation.On their "first date" he makes Cindy laugh. Cindy is not given to laughter. With medical school way down her line of vision, with studying and classes filling her time, Cindy is not spontaneous nor does she particularly want to be. The death of the family dog pretty much initiates final death throes of this ill-fated union. Dean schedules a silly overnight stay at a themed hotel to ramp up the passion. It does not work.The downward spiral escalates. He forces her to acknowledge her feelings. Death, nothing in her heart but dead feelings. Where did they land?Ryan Gosling is simply amazing as the very annoying, very charming Dean, bound on a road to either ruin or redemption. reviewText: Perhaps more than any other film in 2010, I have eagerly anticipated the arrival of "Blue Valentine." After superlative press at Sundance, the film fell into the most ridiculous and unnecessary scandal of the year when the MPAA branded the movie with a NC-17 rating. A film filled with grown-up emotions and intimacies, "Blue Valentine" is an unlikely target for such a rating (in an era filled with movies of extreme violence, gore, and much more nudity) other than the fact that "Blue Valentine" feels so extraordinarily real. Luckily, the rating was rightfully overturned so the picture could enjoy a wider release and the benefits of a more extensive advertising campaign. "Blue Valentine" is a sophisticated and smart entertainment for adult audiences brought to realistic fruition by the stellar Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams. Naturalistic and utterly believable, rarely has a film been able to dissect a relationship with such savvy attention to detail.You might have heard that "Blue Valentine" is a story about the dissolution of a relationship, about a couple growing apart. I would contend, however, that it is instead a contemporary love story. Set in alternate timelines, "Blue Valentine" charts Gosling and Williams both at the beginning of their courtship as well as when their marriage is nearing an end. Shot in an easy improvised style, the earlier moments have charming tenderness while the later segments have a quiet poignancy and sadness. Instead of opting for big scenes and pinpointing singular causes, "Blue Valentine" simply has our couple drifting down different paths. Neither is the particular cause of the estrangement, but Williams pulls back emotionally as Gosling holds on frantically. Both want what's best for each other and their daughter, although they no longer see eye to eye about what that is. Truthful, excruciating, and intimate--"Blue Valentine" plants us in the middle.Gosling and Williams are, in a word, extraordinary. I have, for many years, declared Ryan Gosling perhaps the best actor of his generation. Ever since he burst onto the film scene in the controversial "The Believer," Gosling has eschewed being a mainstream "star." Heck, after "The Notebook," another actor might have taken a very different career path. But Gosling, despite a couple of disappointing forays into big budget Hollywood, has remained true to his indie roots. And Williams has left her "Dawson's Creek" past way behind her as she continues to choose interesting and meaningful projects. They work off each other with ease. The film was improvisational in nature and many scenes are made real by Williams and Gosling playing off one another extemporaneously. Now that's true indie cinema!Anyone who's been in a relationship and/or a break up will be able to identify with the inherent realness behind "Blue Valentine." There are little moments of silliness, big moments of anger, and everything in between. "Blue Valentine" expertly juxtaposes the different stages of this coupling and the results are both terrifically funny and awesomely sad. Pretty much like life itself, huh? A great modern romance about breaking up, "Blue Valentine" is easily one of the year's least contrived and most heartfelt films. And it contains two of the year's best performances! About 4 1/2 stars--rounding up for Gosling and Williams. KGHarris, 1/11.

reviewText: I am a die-hard fan of Ryan Gosling, but for some reason life's business left me in the dark about this movie.  I had no clue what it was about, but love his independent nature and courageous role choices, so I "had" to get this movie when I heard about it.That said, I figured this would be a nice "relaxing" movie..Heck, it's a love story, right?  It has the word, "Valentine" in it.  Well, yes, but it also has the word, "Blue" in it, which is more about how this movie plays out.  It is devastatingly sad.Ryan plays a lovable, blue-collar working man, Dean.  He has worked a variety of odd jobs, but doesn't allow his job or income to determine who he is inside.  He is a very nice guy; compassionate, emotional, and, as usually comes with that package, a bit irresponsible.  He has his issues--but he has no false pretense about them. He drinks from first thing in the morning and smokes like a chimney.  He would rather play with his daughter than be a "dad" with rules.  He steps up to the plate when he is forced to, (such as burying the family dog), but he is filled with sadness and emotion--for example, he can't tell his daughter that her dog is dead; he instead tells her (through tear filled eyes and choking voice) that the dog went off to Hollywood to become a big star--she had the looks, after all.  I do think that he quits seeing his wife for who she is--he becomes more about playing the good guy with his daughter and letting his wife be the "heavy".  It's a cycle that I think many parents get into.Michelle Williams (another great independent actress) plays Cindy, a girl who at first seems one thing but quickly becomes another.  She is complicated, with a sordid past, and the choices she has made play themselves out in not-so-pleasant ways, often leaving Dean paying the price.  They don't get into what in her past made her behave as she does, but they give definite details as to some of the scenes in her life that make her cold hearted.  She is a nurse, and she desperately wants her husband to become "something bigger and better".  (He doesn't understand what she's talking about, as he doesn't define bigger or better as what he does for a living, but rather in the love he surrounds himself with.)  She is angry, and gets angrier throughout the movie.  She stops seeing him as her husband and lover, and sees him as embarrassing and a disappointment.  She humors him, but her anger wins out.  Her drinking doesn't help, either.This movie is a yo-yo.  One minute it shows the present time, the next flashes back to their beginnings.  The artistic nature of the film leaves you unable to walk away, yet you hate to see what you know is the probable outcome.  You don't want the hurt to happen, but you can't stop watching--like a train wreck.  It is alternately intimate and then intense, loving and hating, caring and apathetic.They do magnificent jobs portraying their characters.  You don't question for a minute who they are or where they are coming from.  You feel what they feel.  You see what they see.  Mostly, I think the movie is given from Dean's viewpoint (perhaps because he is more open, perhaps it is for some artistic reason--or perhaps it is only because I identified with his character).Many of these scenes are acted out in real day-to-day life, in every relationship.  Friends, lovers, marriage or other long-term partners...we all go through these things.  At the end of this movie, it asks YOU, the viewer, "Is this you?"  I believe that we could all use that bit of self-reflection.  Could it be me?  Could it be us?  What can I do to not get to where these two are?This movie left me exhausted.  It is so raw, so real...and deeply sad.I do recommend it, though.  Even with all of this--maybe because of all of this--it is a great movie.

reviewText: I doubt that this movie will do much for most people. It is drawn out, windy and stagnant. Yes, the critics are correct in their assessment: it was well crafted, well written and greatly acted - the characters were believable, multidimensional, and understood their parts intimately; it was a technically great movie, adhering beautifully to meter, rhyme and figure of speech - as Dr. J. Evans Pritchard, Ph.D. from "Dead Poet's Society" in his book "Understanding Poetry" would say. But the movie left sort of a blah aftertaste in my mouth. I think that's the case because it doesnt really have a plot or moves along, or even carries some kind of a meaningful message that would make up for its otherwise overly dramatic, whiny tone. For two hours you sit through this movie and really dont understand what the bottom line is; what the commotion is all about and what these characters actually want."Blue Valentine" is a micro-dissection of a failing marriage that is filled with a lot of pain, tears and melodrama, which at some point felt exaggerated because the characters never express any other emotions. They are sad and gloomy ALL THE TIME and no one knows why it has to be so darn difficult. The movie follows Dean (Ryan Gosling) and Cindy (Michelle Williams) falling in and out of love over a short period of courtship and childbirth, flashing back and forth from present to when they met.While the illogical nature of love is one of my favorite topics, here it feels pointless on the screen. Many weighty elements dont seem to be meditated on by the filmmaker, and one of the question that inevitably arises is Why are they Fighting? o ok, these two people got married young for the wrong reasons and now it is not working out for one of them. Why is that such a big deal and the end of the world and grounds for so much drama and gut-wrenching pain? It is not like they were the greatest, most profound lovers, so why should we care? After two hours of tedious back and forth, tears and drama, you still can't see point.The folly with "Blue Valentine" is that it never answers the most important question: Why? Why are these people fighting and why did they fall in love? Have they simply grown apart? Did Cindy finally realize she married him to get out of the house and not because she was in love with him? Or maybe they're just insufferable people who have no business trying to love another person.  None of these questions are really answered or even eluded to really. It just shows you they are sad and suffering, and sad and suffering. Sure you can make intuitive guesses as to the source of the conflict, of growing apart, of the alienation, but there is no evidence for it in the story. There is just a severe disconnect between the flashbacks of a supposedly happier time between the two lovers and the dreary present. In fact, one cannot even see the love between Cindy and Dean that supposedly existed in the beginning.This movie would have us believe that there existed some kind of a truly passionate, loving relationship between the two which, in turn, is making their separation from one another even more painful.But the reality looked different. No passion, love and sincere feelings between the two. All throughout the movie I kept wondering what one saw in the other and why anyone would think that they really loved each other as clearly Cindy didnt love Dean. In fact, she is selfish, cold and unlikable and throughout the movie she seems kind of insincere toward Dean; like she was merely putting up with him and their child until the life she really wanted came along.The two time periods shown in the film seem drastically far apart. There aren't any scenes of the genesis of their relationship that point to the present turmoil, connecting the two disparate worlds. How, why, did they change so much and why did they fall in love in the first place? It's crucial to good storytelling that there's some explanation of what went wrong or the motives and driving forces behind the characters' actions -- and if not, it at least should be made clear that this is a story about how - in spite of no specific reason - sometimes these things happen.These people got together for the same reason millions of other young people get together: boredom, the need for companionship, destitution or a desire to "get out of your parents' house" under the belief that married live somehow holds the secret to happiness. Cindy and Dean are one of those people. They arent special, they didnt have a great love, nothing earth shaking that would make it to the "biggest love stories of all time" happened.If crucial narrative pivots are left too open-ended, a story is destined to lose its voice. While Gosling and Williams inhabit their roles fully, one quickly realizes that the failure to connect leads to the audience feeling lost, unable to empathize or fully understand why any of this is happening or why the characters are behaving the way they do.I must also mention that Goseling was miscast He is being made to act and behave older than he can pull off and that beard of his looked like one of those glued on beards in school plays. Michelle Williams' character was not very likable and in fact so selfish that it was hard to sympathize with her from the beginning - which is not the movie's intention obviously. If a character portrayal evokes the exact opposite feeling in the audience than originally intended, you know something is off.In summary, while well crafted, this movie did feel like slowly pulling hairs for no apparent reason. They stretched out a simple story and artificially created an elaborate drama for two hours over a subject that could have been resolved in twenty minutes of film time. In the end this movie was just as pointless as Dean's and Cindy's courtship, and eventual marriage.
summary: Like Digging in Your Flesh to Remove a Splinter for Two Hours and Never Getting It Out

reviewText: Dean (Ryan Gosling) and Cindy (Michelle Williams) are a young couple whose marriage is in trouble.  In an attempt to salvage the relationship, they spend a night away from their daughter in a motel, but things do not go as well as they had hoped.Simultaneous with this bleak look at their present lives, we visit the beginnings of Dean and Cindy's romance, a time filled with music, dance and all the other silly stuff that people do when they are falling in love.And, then we try to answer the question, what happened to make that all change?When it comes to showing the disintegration of a marriage, I don't think it was done any better than the breakfast montage in Orson Welles' CITIZEN KANE.  That sequence was about two minutes in length and it really said everything you needed to know about why the relationship failed.In BLUE VALENTINE, director Derek Cianfrance and his co-writers attempt to dig deeper into the reason(s) that love dies and people who have committed their lives to each other part.He has come up with an excellent, albeit depressing, script that often rings true, and he has elicited superb performances from his actors.  Ms. Williams, in fact, received a Best Actress Oscar nomination for her role.On the other hand, despite the emotional grittiness of the piece, the ultimate answer that Cianfrance presents us with is nothing that we haven't heard before: "People change.  They grow apart."As we learn about halfway through the picture, as much as they were in love at the time, Dean and Cindy probably married for the wrong reasons.  Yet, when they finally part, one can't help but think that this union, with some counseling, could have been saved.Based on his background (i.e. his parents divorced), I can certainly understand why Cianfrance would want to write/direct this film and, because they are great roles, I can understand  why fine actors like Gosling and Williams would want to play them.What I can't understand is, as well-made as the picture is, why somebody seeking to be "entertained" would want to see it. reviewText: There have been many powerful films about the breakup of a marriage, but most of them--such as "Scenes from a Marriage" and "Shoot the Moon"--have concentrated on affluent couples. Derek Cianfrance's "Blue Valentine" is all the more heartbreaking for portraying a working-class couple whose love is destroyed by continuing, unremitting bad luck.Cianfrance doesn't give us all the details of how Dean (Ryan Gosling) and Cindy (Michelle Williams) fall out of love; he tells the story in non-linear fashion, contrasting the couple's bitter present with their (relatively) sweet past. He dares to juxtapose the moment in Dean and Cindy's past when they fall in love--she does a softshoe to his ukulele version of "You Always Hurt the One You Love"--with the exact moment in the present when they fall out of love, a joyless encounter in an "adult motel" that Dean thought would respark the passion in their marriage. ("Blue Valentine" barely escaped a dreaded NC-17 rating.)Gosling and Williams give two of the most powerful, emnotionally naked performances you will ever see, and "Blue Valentine"--though not exactly a pleasurable film--will leave you shaken and deeply moved. Dean and Cindy, Cianfrance tells us, are two people whose lives have been defined by pain and misfortune. The supreme, sad irony is that marrying each other may have been their greatest misfortune.
summary: A heartbreaking film about love destroyed.

reviewText: Nine Things about the Movie “Blue Valentine” [USA, 2010]1. This movie is a brave portrayal of the last part of a relationship, when “Happily Ever After” turns out to be false.2. It was written and directed by Derek Cianfrance. It stars Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams. Three years after this move was made, Gosling and Cianfrance paired up again for “The Place Beyond the Pines”.3. The movie moves back and forth between two times: The first is the “love at first sight” period when they genuinely believe they will be together forever. The second is the disintegration period some five years later, when they realize “for better or worse” is not what they expected.. The genius here is that eventually you realize you are sometimes seeing almost the same scene being depicted in each period...but with different circumstances.4. Gosling and Williams have a genuine, believable chemistry. You believe that they are in love, and you believe the bitterness that grows between them. They should have won some kind of acting award for their performances.5. To make it more realistic, Gosling and Williams acted like a couple before filming the downhill slide. They rented a house together, and lived according to their characters’ budgets.6. In some of the scenes, Gosling and Williams went without scripted dialogue; they improvised it as they were being filmed.7. The power of the movie comes not only from the big arguments the couple has, but the small moments, too: the ignored caress, the eyes that hide the truth, the awkward silences.8. At first, the film got an NC-17 rating, for it’s depiction of Michelle Williams receiving oral sex. The rating was appealed, and Gosling accused the ratings board of sexism and misogyny, noting that plenty of movies depict males receiving oral sex, and it’s not considered a big deal. The rating was changed to R.9. None of the relationships in the movie are happy, not even the long-lasting ones. Everyone is dealing with the death of love in some form or another. Well, unless they are admitting that they never felt it in the first place.
