Then the part where he's trying to cheering her up because he's finally spending a weekend with his wife, and all she's trying to do is make him a better man by asking him what his hopes and dreams are, and the two conflicting intentions consistently building a tension so palpable you could almost feel it through the screen.When they were in love it was as if the world opened up to them, and even when she'd fallen out of love with him, there were still glimpses of caring and affection. The part where they looked for his ring in the bushes together, or when he punched that smug doctor in the face.The part where he asked her to have a baby with him, and she shut him down - it's crazy how he tries to save the marriage and imagines a life where it's so simple and lovey dovey. It's not that he's not complex, it's that he has actually figured out some of the finer things in life, figured out what's important - family, and love. But she's much more complex than that and the audience only got a glimpse of it. Their pasts speak volumes as to who they are as characters - he comes from a simple family and does a simple job, and she comes from a history of complexity and needs that in order to thrive.I can't help but ask Ryan's character, "How do you recover from a situation like that?" From a broken marriage with a child who's not yours, when you try and try and everything seems to fail. When you come in as the white in shining armor, and leave depleted, waking away from the only love that you ever knew. Like a silhouette of memories just walking away.The part where the kid chases after Dean and tries to pull his arm back, almost like she intuitively knew that this might been the end - that part killed me.Why is Michelle so good at portraying these tragic tragic complex characters? I don't get it. She was great in this movie, and now nominated for an Oscar for her role in Marilyn. She has got to be one of the most typcasted "sensual"  characters in history.Ryan Gosling delivers a very good performance. The dynamic between his outer strength and inner weaknesses has to be noted. He has childlike qualities about him that brings out his charm, his confidence exhumed at first when he first met her but eventually faded as his love for her and her consistent rejection chewed away at his ego. He really just needed a good friend to tell him "hey back the f off, she cares about you but you gotta let her breathe, you're suffocating her." He needed someone to tell him "Hey she's following through with her dreams, she wants that for you too, she doesn't want a husband who wastes away at a mindless job when he's capable of ten times more."In the end he asks, "what will it take? What can I do? I'll change, you tell me what you want me to do?" And she could have said, "Follow your own dreams, be a man, don't let me carry the financial and mental stability of this relationship!" And maybe it would have worked, but instead all that was left between them was the silence, and the memories of the love that was but could never be again.

reviewText: The first time I watched "Blue Valentine" (or tried to), I didn't finish it. It simply did not hold my interest. So I put the movie aside, didn't think it fair to review a film I hadn't watched through, and pretty much forgot about it. Then, the other day, I saw the DVD and thought I'd give it another try. I won't repeat the plot as it's been summarized quite adequately in other reviews. I'll just share my reactions.I was quite impressed by the performances of the leads, Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams. I know that Williams received the Oscar nomination, but I thought Gosling's performance truly amazing. He's nuanced when necessary and over the top when the script calls for that. In a film that jumps around in its structure, I thought both actors played their parts letter perfect. (I'm not really sure why this point impresses me so much. After all, even the most linear films are typically shot completely out of order, so actors are always called upon to act out of order.) I also had to admire the crafting of the director, Derek Cianfrance, and the writers, Cianfrance, Joey Curtis, and Cami Delavigne. "Blue Valentine" is clearly a carefully put-together film and shows both planning and intelligence in its structure.The problem, though, is that I didn't want to be admiring performances, direction, or writing. I wanted to be more involved in the plot and the characters. And, unfortunately, I simply wasn't all that sucked in. By no means did I find the film boring or unpleasant to watch, but seeing it wasn't the all-enveloping experience that the best films offer. So I've given it four stars to reflect the artistry of the participants and my willingness to see their work again.

reviewText: I almost gave this five stars just for the performances but, after reading a number of other reviews, I realize that there were problems with the script that made me subtract a star.In the "Special Features" on the DVD, the writer/director states that he made this film, which is truly a highly personal labor of love, to come to grips with the pain he felt at ten years when his own parents divorced.  Maybe he should have written about those real people because the two characters he wrote in this script are not convincing.  He invented two characters, each from unhappy homes who marry too early for the wrong reasons and who are doomed to fail at marriage.  But the actors he has hired for the jobs are so beautiful and likeable that we really want them to make it.If he had just dropped his personal agenda of making a film about a doomed marriage, and let his characters have their way, this might have been a much more plausible story.  These two, as brought to life by Williams and Gosling, might just have found a way to make their relationship work.  The part of the film that shows their falling in love is so charming and deeply moving that the second part which shows their breakup just leaves us devastated.  This isn't just a complaint because it lacks a traditional Hollywood Happy Ending....it's an ending that doesn't make sense out of what the film has shown us.That said, there is a lot in the film to love.  The acting is wonderful.  Michelle Williams plays vulnerable better than almost any actress I can think of.  Ryan Gosling is amazing!  I had never seen him in any other films and I was blown away by his performance here.  There are some deleted scenes on the DVD, mostly of the two in their early, romantic period, that are priceless.  They rival the best of the Diane Keaton/Woody Allen scenes from "Annie Hall."The film reminded me of the films of John Cassavetes, which were largely improvisational and achieved the same deeply authentic and moving performances.  I think that if the director had stepped aside and let a writer who was less invested in the story re-write the script, a truly memorable film could have been made.  Still, if you don't care a lot about the actual story, it's worth watching just for the many touching and realistic moments.

reviewText: BLUE VALENTINE is a low budget film, telling us about the beginning and end of a marriage.  It stars Ryan Gosling & Michelle Williams.  The movie shows us "now" over the space of just a couple of days, as we see this couple along with their roughly 5 year old child, going through mundane tasks and the final arguments that lead to their split.  The film also bounces back to the few weeks or months from their first meeting until the day they get married.  We see them about 5 or 6 years younger, nave & sweetly in-love.  When we bounce to the present, we seem them harried, worried and barely able to tolerate each other.Some would say that the film makes a broad statement on how love or marriage can go from sweet to sour.  How we sabotage our happiness.  How difficult it is to make a happy marriage (or for the true cynics, how IMPOSSIBLE it is).I took NO global message from the film.  It is powerful, but it is very small in scope.  This is because the filmmaker Derek Cianfrance has made a deeply SPECIFIC movie.  Gosling & Williams give VERY lived-in performances where we very much feel we are looking at a very particular couple going through very particular joys and disappointments.  We feel like we're getting a very intimate peek into what makes this particular couple tick.  Thus, it becomes nearly impossible to extrapolate the film to the general subject of "marriage."  This is not a failing, per se...but I've certainly read comments on the film that imply that very thing.  That is absurd, quite frankly.  Each marriage has its own rhythms, pulses, occurrences & secrets.  The relationship depicted here feels real, because it is so specific.  It also feels small.To me, the main reason to see this film is for the performances.  Both stars do their best work here...by a long way.  Williams has given some nice performances in the past (BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN, WENDY & LUCY)...but often her performances have been of women more or less drained by life.  Williams, particularly in the early scenes, is full of undirected ambition and spirit.  She's eager to get away from her terrible homelife and is smart enough to have career ambitions, even though this is not something that runs in her family.  She's very close to her grandmother, but terrorized by her parents, who have vicious arguments that she must endure.  She makes lousy choices in men.  Gosling is new to the big city (NYC) and nave.  He's poorly educated, and not terribly ambitious.  He's not seen anything for himself other than getting away from his own sad family situation.  He's a terribly nice guy (his early scene with a senior citizen he doesn't even know is touching, heartbreaking and puts us forever on his side)...but has little to offer other than devoted, puppy-dog love.  The two have a passionate and convincing early romance...but when they take the step to marriage, we also see that from the first day, the seeds of end of the marriage have already been planted.  I won't give specifics...but let's just say that not enough of their paths are converging for this thing to really have a shot.  For them, marriage is an escape from demons...and we see they are bringing some of the demons right along with them.In the later scenes, as they fight and old bitterness comes out...we are able to pretty much guess just how the five years since the wedding day have gone by.  Gosling has spent his time in menial jobs, showing no inclination to move up.  Williams, because she now has a family, has put her ambitions on the back burner.  She's a nurse, but she's also by far the primary breadwinner.  The two seem to have a comfortable lower middle-class life...but their paths have diverged (Gosling is barely even on a path.)I suspect the film wants us to feel good and bad for each of them in equal measure.  To not take sides...but to simply feel bad for both and to wish they could find a way to get it together.  However, my experience and that of my wife, was that we very much took sides (both with the same person)...and this somewhat diminishes the power of the film.  It's not meant to be a good vs. bad movie...but it sort of ends up that way.This is not a happy film...but there's plenty of wry humor.  (And if you've heard about the graphic sex that initially got this film an NC-17...you'll likely scratch your head at that.  The sex in BLACK SWAN was far more "shocking.")  It's also not as depressing as perhaps you've heard.  Again, because we're watching a film that ISN'T about our own marriage.  Our marriage is very different.  We see this couple and feel for them...but we don't sit there and think, "OMG, this is SO much like my marriage."  (Thank goodness.)  Granted, this is a very personal response from me...others may feel differently.You should absolutely see the film, though.  It features two of the very best American performances this year.  And despite seeming like we're just watching home movies, it is actually very artfully photographed.  And as a bonus, it features the most outrageous cheap hotel room in film history.  (Don't ask...just see for yourself.)
summary: 4.5 stars for one of the best acted films of the year

reviewText: Set in a rural, working-class area of Pennsylvania, Derek Cianfrance's "Blue Valentine" provides us with the anatomy of an unhappy marriage.Like Stanley Donen's far more scintillating 1967 film "Two for the Road," "Blue Valentine" takes us back and forth to various stages in the couple's relationship.  We see them in the present day as Dean (Ryan Gosling) and Cindy (Michelle Williams) struggle to hold it together, growing increasingly distant from one another both emotionally and romantically.  We also see, in counterpoint, the earlier stages of their courtship, when their love was new and exciting and the future filled with infinite possibility and hope.  This non-linear narrative structure serves only to underline and intensify the sadness of the present day.Perhaps the most audacious - and, for some viewers, no doubt, frustrating - aspect of the film is the characters' reluctance to articulate their thoughts and feelings about their relationship.  We sense that they are angry, irritated and disappointed with their lives and each other, but we're rarely told why, although Dean's alcoholism appears to be a key factor in the couple's disintegration.  The root of the problem appears to be a general state of ennui that afflicts many, if not most, couples after they've spent a certain amount of time together.  Thus, "Blue Valentine" becomes an almost impressionistic look at a crumbling relationship, comprised of the little day-to-day moments and activities that, when added together, create a fully developed picture.  Moreover, there is one beautifully executed, harrowing sequence in which a drunken Dean confronts Cindy at the hospital where she works that is a model of naturalistic filmmaking.Yet, the movie's greatest strength also happens to be its greatest weakness.  For there are  times when the film seems to want us to congratulate it for saying something incisive and profound when it really isn't saying anything at all.Still, Gosling and Williams have probably never been better than they are here, as they tackle their roles with absolute realism and conviction.  Moreover, an eclectic score (by Grizzly Bear) that often plays against the mood of the scene and a bravely inconclusive ending counterbalance the movie's occasional lack of articulation and insight.
summary: Impressionistic look at a crumbling relationship

reviewText: I've been reading so many other reviews, comments and postings of this movie and see people's responses are everywhere. I don't think with this movie that is odd whatsoever. It is opinion scattering. This story did not allow me to look away from the painful scenario of it. The plot is not too complicated; the condition of a love gone over to complete dysfunction. This is in no way a feel good movie ... not even close. Their situations are made to make you run through some intense emotions. I don't believe you are supposed to feel anywhere near hopeful for this agonizing, emotionally drained couple and for their circumstance when you are through with the movie. The entire mood of the film is dismal; not much lighting, the foreboding overcast days with rainy weather, moody night shots, the bored feel of their small town, the dilapidated look of the main characters home all pull a negative statement.Husband Dean, portrayed by Oscar nominated Ryan Gosling and his wife counterpart Cindy, portrayed by Oscar nominated (this picture)  Michelle Williams are wonderfully convincing together, and have a palpable onscreen chemistry.  Their younger years are shown to the audience through flashbacks. So many uncomfortable ones for me to learn a lot of information of their psychological pasts which explain so much of what is happening while the movie plays through to the present time. Starting here, in their younger lives, as they are so important and relevant to the whole demise of the marriage. I seemed to see quite a bit about these two at this point in time.Dean, who seemed the less complicated person to understand for me, was (and remained) hard working and took whatever menial job that he could get by with. I saw him as a pretty interactive person, social with his co-workers, laughing often and empathetic. In a wonderfully showing scene with an elderly gentleman (Walter) we are treated to just how caring he most certainly is. These nurturing qualities would be greatly needed in a future father.  One could easily see the extra time and special way he gave Walter dignity and pride while introducing him to his new living quarters, this happened to be where Cindy's beloved grandmother was staying for a time also. There really isn't too much background to look at as far as Dean personally except for his ability for putting the needs of others before himself. I could find several upsetting problems befalling Cindy in her upbringing. She, in sharp contrast to Dean, is not happy and quite cynical. She comes from an abusive family background from some very showing scenes which seemingly cause self-esteem issues. In her relationship with her high school boyfriend is the point where you should start seeing red flags. He mistreats her, is cruel with her feelings, and is downright abusive with her at times. Cindy has not had a relationship that is healthy, with the exception of her grandmother.  The two meet at the nursing home. Dean sees her from around Walter's new room and seems immediately smitten with her, this is how they begin. Aside from the normal infatuation stage, these two seem as if they have two completely different dispositions. One of the flashback recollections I thought pertinent was the joke that Cindy tells to Dean on the bus - it made me cringe. It sure didn't appear that Dean was comfortable with it whatsoever while she laughs about it. Did that joke make you laugh?To really appreciate this movie for what it is, one should always keep in mind how Cindy has been treated in her relationships during her lifetime which is arguably with an abusive element involved. Dean does not show any penchant for abuse at all and especially towards her. He does not understand her comfort with things being painful considering his nurturing capabilities.  With many things Cindy does it appears she does not have a whole lot of empathy. With Dean she is mostly cold and shut-off, then towards her daughter Frankie she can be neglectful of her safety and of her care at times.  This is easily shown at the breakfast time as the movie opens. She also forgets the recital while Dean sits fidgeting until virtually the end before Cindy runs in.During the scenes with Cindy and her father, there is a comfortable relationship between them even though he was a large part of her abusive upbringing.  Dean is left out or looked down on by the man as being an outcast in the family. He is Cindy's husband treated with so much disregard and disrespect at the tragic ending of the film, which is gut-wrenching between Frankie and her father.  I think in all this pain is how this film actually played truthfully. If not to bring out your strongest feelings towards the characters and their situations then why play certain things out during this heartbreaking unraveling of their family?  The characters all made me feel several different emotions; anger, a scant glimmer of nostalgia, fear, abandonment, loss, and a pervasive sadness that permeates this film. It basically infiltrated my own thoughts and influenced my state of mind for a long while after watching.So many have penned this movie as pointless. A movie such as this can push every button of feeling one has left until it's ending when you are exhausted. It's as if you have been through it yourself and you've only watched it play out through characters. May I reiterate; this is not a feel good movie and is not supposed to be. For myself, it is amazing for being an exhausting study of just the opposite.

reviewText: If you would like a front row seat to a failing marriage, this is your movie.  It alternates between scenes of a couple (played by Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams) six years into their marriage, and flashbacks that tell the story of how they met and married.  You've probably seen couples like this, where every statement one partner makes seems to provoke a "What's THAT supposed to mean?" response from the other.  So if you'd like to watch that for a couple of hours, by all means see this movie.I am giving it 3 stars because the acting is good, the editing is really good, and the whole thing "feels real" (as I said earlier, you've probably seen couples like this).  I would quibble a bit with some of the blurbs I've seen about the film's brillance.  For example, that it is told in an "innovative style."  They're flashbacks, folks.  If that's innovative, then "It's a Wonderful Life" is also told in an innovative style.  Or, as one of the reviews on the DVD box says, the film says "something real about love."  Well, it certainly portrays an unhappy relationship in an unflinching and  realistic way.  I wouldn't say that elevates the film to making some sort of profound universal statement about the nature of love or relationships (unless the truth is, "some relationships end badly" or "some people don't belong together"...neither of which seem that profound).Special features are fairly standard:  a commentary track, some deleted scenes that (as always) definitely needed to be deleted, and some "home movies" of the characters that I didn't bother to watch, because I felt like I kinda got it (there is a scene where the characters watch these, which is why I assume they were shot in the first place).

reviewText: This is a small gem of a film, and one of the best of the year. After an enormous battle with the MPAA to get the initial NC-17 rating overturned, the film opened to critical acclaim, yet was unmercifully snubbed at the Oscars this year. This is a shame, because this film features two of the best performances that you are likely to see all year, and it is also a raw, powerful experience that you will never forget.This film tells the story of Dean Pereira (Ryan Gosling) and Cindy Heller (Michelle Williams), a high school drop out and a medical student, who meet by chance in a nursing home. Dean is immediately love-struck with Cindy, and begins to pursue her from that point on. He eventually wins her over with his charm and musical talents, and the two become an item. As the relationship evolves, things get serious, and they eventually decide to get married.The film constantly shifts back and forth between time periods, from the initial stages of their relationship, to where they are presently. Dean is a borderline alcoholic who has given up on his dreams of being a musician in order to paint houses to make a living. Cindy is a nurse at a hospital, who constantly tries to deal with Dean's constant mood shifts and childlike behavior. Dean is a good father and husband, but he is clearly struggling with some serious demons. Cindy is a good mother, but the love that she has for her husband has taken on a note of ambiguity. Dean makes an ill-timed attempt to reconcile with his wife at a dingy motel, and it only serves to complicate matters even further. When he drunkenly stumbles in to her workplace, demanding an explanation for her seemingly frigid behavior, there is no doubt that this marriage is in serious jeopardy. The gritty details are laid out before us, and upon reflection, it is clear that things were headed this way from the very beginning.Michelle Williams and Ryan Gosling are fantastic in their roles. They tear up the screen, lay their emotions on the table, and rip our hearts out in the process. This is a reality check from director Derek Cianfrance, who gives the film a gritty look and feel that haunts you after the credits roll.  This is not your typical love story. This is the anti-Notebook - and you should not miss it.Blue Valentine is rated R, on appeal from a previous NC-17 rating, for strong graphic sexual content, language, and a beating. 112 minutes. The Weinstein Company.
summary: 'Blue Valentine' is a gritty love story with powerful performances

reviewText: "Blue Valentine"  is the story of a romantic relationship -- not flourishing, but turning from unbridled joy to utter bitterness.  It is not an easy movie to watch and doesn't provide the typical Hollywood ending.  For that reason alone, the movie is a noteworthy commentary on relationships based on infatuation and little substance.Dean (Ryan Gosling) works for a Brooklyn moving company.  He first meets Cindy (Michelle Williams) when his company assigns him to relocate an elderly man to a Scranton nursing home on the same day she is visiting her sick grandmother there.  Dean is immediately smitten and later returns to Scranton to look for her.  He finds her and she falls for his lovesick charms, even though she has a boyfriend (Mitch Vogel).Cindy has ambitions.  She attends college, is a good student, and aspires to a career in medicine.  Dean is a high school dropout who thinks little about the future and is content with a life that offers him little chance of improvement.Director Derek Cianfrance provides a raw, non-glossy look at a relationship deteriorating before our eyes.  He gives the film a documentary feel as the dialogue reveals the pain of the two young people as they see that their union is not working.  The scene shifts back and forth from the past, shown in washed-out hues, and the present, in full color.  This kind of character study used to be referred to as a "slice of life" - an unglomorous, uncompromising, unadorned glimpse into the lives of real people."Blue Valentine" works primarily because of the two leads. Both Gosling and Williams are excellent and involve us as we watch the darker sides of their natures come to the surface.  They infuse their characters with humanity and passion, veering far afield from the kind of starry-eyed, often airhead partnerings the movies often present as typical.Blu-ray extras include director's audio commentary, a making-of featurette, and deleted scenes.

reviewText: I am not sure that a modern love story could get more painfully dramatic or a fictional couple experience more tragic circumstances than Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams in Blue Valentine.  This was a touching story, carefully pieced together and subtle.  A diamond in the rough, if you ask me.We see a couple.  To be blunt, they are white trash.  Ryan Gosling is losing his hair, smokes incessantly, and spends most of the day in a drunken stupor.  It is the only way he can make it through the torture of his menial painting job and underachiever lot in life.  Michelle Williams has likely put on a few pounds since high school, sports tacky fake nails, and doesn't do much to style her dishwater blonde hair.  She works as a hospital nurse but really wanted to go to med school.  The couple loves their young daughter.  Our first glimpses of the couple lead us to believe that they could be any lower-middle class couple struggling to pay the bills in America.  But there is more.The flashbacks begin.  We see how Gosling's character was a roustabout and a high school dropout.  Not knowing what to do, he joins a moving company in Brooklyn for a steady paycheck.  By chance, he meets Williams's character while moving a decrepit old man into an assisted living center.  Williams is caring for her ailing grandmother, who she clearly loves.  Gosling hits on Williams, but she is too young, shy, and struck to nibble back.Plus, Williams is in an unhappy relationship with an overpowering jock college student.  He treats her poorly, even sexually abusing her in one scene.  (She ends up pregnant from the encounter.)  This glimpse is foreshadowing of later scenes in which we learn more about Williams's character's sexual history and witness, to my recollection, the first on-screen abortion procedure.  This is real and painful stuff, folks.  Not graphic and gory, but it turns your stomach.  Not for the faint of heart.Williams and Gosling ultimately connect and fall in love.  One particularly affecting element of Blue Valentine is its sharp appreciation for how personal and magical love is.  It is inside jokes.  It is "our song."  It is is being unapologetically silly and not caring what anyone else thinks.  It is public displays of affection.  It is finding joy in the simple.  It has been a long time since I have seen a film that captures all of this so well.And then life seems to intercede for the couple.  Dreams go largely unrealized.  Potential is left on the shelf to expire.  The past shows its ugly head.  The present is awful and filled with suspicion, disappointment, and struggle.  The love that was once there is buried, maybe crushed by adulthood and responsibility.  The film does not end on a high note.We get great performances by Williams and Gosling.  The most impressive aspect is how they seamlessly transition from young and full of hope to slightly older and broken.  It is more than just altered appearance; it is a transformation that takes stamina and diving deep inside the role to "get" why the character has so much angst and sadness.I recommend this film.  As love stories go, this is probably one more for guys than gals.  It is not lighthearted, but you will learn something about life and love.
summary: A love story for the guys.

reviewText: A friend of mine raved about this movie last year and put this on my radar. I normally wouldn't pay much attention to a movie like this but with her rave reviews, I decided to give it a go. I was very pleasantly surprised by what I found.The story flashes from present to past, giving glimpses into an unhappily married couple, Dean and Cindy, and their early life together. There is tension in the air, unspoken angers  that bob the surface of this marriage and the only thing that the couple seem happy about is their daughter. But as you see flashes of the past, you realize that they hadn't always been this way. They started off happy, funny, silly and in love. Dean seems like a funny if juvenile young man who immediately decides to marry and build a family with Cindy when he discovers she is pregnant(not his child). Though their relationship is very young at that point, he wants to do the right thing and believes, naively as later facts will prove, that they can make it work. Cindy on the other hand is the product of a loveless and emotionally abusive marriage. She has her first sexual experience at thirteen and by the time we meet her in her later teens, her number of sexual partners is in the twenties. Before Dean, she is with a guy who seems like a jerk though the movie never makes it clear why she thinks so. When she meets and begins to date Dean, it seems like she is destined to live a very different life from her parents.One thing that surprised me about this movie was that this was a young couple who had already grown so bitter and so angry with each other. Usually this kind of anger is portrayed in couples who had been together for many more years, raised children and have now grown fed up of each other. But Cindy and Dean seem to have imbibed all of the aforementioned bitterness despite their youth. This makes it even sadder because it speaks to an unhappy future life for both, even apart.When my friend first told me about this movie, I assumed I would dislike Cindy. But after viewing the movie, I felt sorry for her. Maybe if she had sought therapy early, before getting in a relationship, maybe she and Dean would have stood a chance. But by the time she meets him, she is such a damaged soul, she doesn't have enough to give to another human being. Cindy comes across as unyielding and mean and though she is all of those things, her accumulation of unfulfilled and unrealized ambition makes her so. It is sad to see the love sour between these two but in some ways it was inevitable. Cindy could never make anyone happy because deep down she wasn't happy herself. The sacrifices that Dean made to be with her which she so appreciated in the beginning become the things she will later hold against him.The performances in this movie were excellent. Michelle Williams and Ryan Gosling play their parts so believably and deserve all the praise they received for this movie.In this movie, love doesn't conquer all.

reviewText: *** This review may contain spoilers ***Watch out! Today's soap opera is all dressed up in documentary style replete with improvised dialogue, graphic sex scenes and a ton of angst hanging in the air. Don't despair however--like any traditional soap opera, rest assured that you will discover that the new soap opera will be just like the old--almost completely lacking in wit, humor or a modicum of 'ideas'.Blue Valentine chronicles the breakdown of a relationship, focusing on two blue collar characters, Dean and Cindy (played with an honest intensity by Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams). Director Derek Cianfrance constantly flashes back and forth between Dean and Cindy's early courtship and the eventual breakdown of their relationship, after they have a child together (played by an adorable five year old, Faith Wladyka).Dean is depicted as a high school dropout who begins working for a moving company and later as a painter. He courts Cindy by singing songs on a ukulele and is supportive of her even after she reveals she's pregnant by another man, Bobby, a sadistic jock who beats up the young Dean after he finds out that he's been dating Cindy.In her younger incarnation, Cindy is an aspiring medical student and is later seen as a nurse in a doctor's office. Cindy's character is even more sketchy. When we first meet her, she's emotionally needy but later when she's 'all grown up', she turns on Dean, simply because he lacks ambition. If Cindy wins no brownie points for her lack of warmth, Dean is positively repulsive after morphing into a love sick puppy dog with an acute alcohol problem. The film's climax takes place at Cindy's place of employment where Dean, completely soused, slugs Cindy's employer in the face, a physician, who promptly retaliates by firing Cindy, who returns home with her husband and demands a divorce.Blue Valentine features some long drawn-out scenes which in part could have been left on the cutting room floor. One such scene is Dean and Cindy's failed tryst at a tacky, futuristic motel room. Yes, we get the point pretty much right away that Cindy no longer has any sexual interest in Dean but we're forced to endure the gyrations until Cindy calls an end to the couple's uncomfortable session together.The contrast between the early joy of Dean and Cindy's relationship and the later dissolution is meant to be sad and no doubt it is. But do we and should we really care? There is nothing inherently dramatic in depicting a dissolution of a marriage unless there are some unique and compelling reasons behind it. Blue Valentine provides us with the most simplistic and sketchy of explanations (as previously mentioned, Cindy's perception that Dean lacks ambition and the brutal reality of his unbridled alcoholism).The Valentine scenarists try hard to provide a psychological context for Cindy's emotional neediness right before her marriage. The explanation is in the form of her churlish, hot-tempered Dad, who is probably the least realized characters in the entire script.If you're looking for a story of ideas, a la Ingmar Bergman, you will not find it here. Rather, all the plot points are one of the standard melodrama, now adorned in modern accouterments. Director Cianfrance is not without talent--he knows how to extract good performances from his actors and works well with his DP and special effects crew (dig those fantastic closing credits). But ultimately, a story about a depressed couple and dissolution of a marriage does not make for good drama. What's missing is the basic element that these characters lack: ego!
summary: Connect the dots tale of blue collar marriage dissolution

reviewText: Blue Valentine is told in flashbacks as well as the present time. The problem with that is in this particular film, the entire middle of the doomed love story between Gosling's character and Williams' character is never really established, rendering the whole movie somewhat pointless. It feels very dragged out but if you stop and really think about it, not much was ever presented to us to gain any knowledge about what happened in their relationship. We see them meet, fall in love, so eager and so overfilled with joy- and then we see them falling apart at the seams. Clearly bored with each other, living in their own world. Some might say that the ambiguity of the film is what makes it work, since we never really find out truly what went wrong, and at what time, we can dream up a scenario or scenarios ourselves and that's fine if you want to think that way, but it seems a bit on the sloppy side.Great performances aside, the film's pace is lacking and there isn't much to hold the interest of the audience. The characters are both extremely flawed, so it really is hard to pinpoint who is to blame for their downward spiral. The husband starts drinking in the morning, has no further ambitions in life than working his usual job, and being a father to a little girl who isn't even his own-but loves her dearly regardless. Then we have a wife who is detached, apparently gossips to her coworkers all the time about her husband, and wants really nothing to do romantically with him. Again, we never, ever see how it progressed to this. You see glimpses of Gosling's character where he seems very loving, and caring and presents himself to be a real gentleman and kind person. And we see Williams' character revealing how many sexual partners she's had and the fact that she was 13 when she lost her virginity. She misses her daughter's play, inadvertently causes the death of their dog, and even briefly thinks about having an affair with her boss. It's a mixed bag here and again, we only see the after-effects of the whole relationship. Without a solid middle, we are left guessing.Blue Valentine could have been a great, powerful film, but it feels very lacking.

reviewText: Blue Valentine is the type of film in which you come away in awe at how well the filmmakers and actors have captured the look and feel of a real-life disaster but alas, leave you wanting to escape. The actors are trapped in tight, claustrophic close-ups and there is almost no music (except for Dean's singing, some strumming on a guitar, and romantic songs occasionally playing in the background). Like a good documentary, it is unsparing in its depiction of how love turns to hate and regret. Perhaps the most bleak moment is when Michelle William's character, Cindy, frustrates Ryan Goesling's attempts to make love by sexually stiffening her body against him. The juxtaposition of their courtship and marriage against the dying embers of their relationship create a lot of pathos, hearthbreak and pain. That said, I was dissatisfied with the film. One: there is almost no humor and there are few scenes of them actually enjoying family life, apart from the early courtship. Two: The Cindy character is woefully underdeveloped. She is made out to be, basically, a slut. We find out that she first had sex at 13 and subsequently 25 partners. In contrast, all we know about Dean is that his mother ran away with another man, presumably making him fearful of abandonment. We never learn why Cindy dislikes him so much; nothing he does in the film seems to justify her dumping him, other than the fact that he's a slacker and is content with a beer. My only interpretation is that she hates men, due to the fact that her father is shown being abusive to her mother. The lack of details about Dean's family life oddly make more sympathetic. While the actors did a wonderful job inhabiting their roles (i don't think I'll see either actor in the same way again), I find it hard to love a movie that depicts a breakup mostly from the guy's point of view.
